backcard.definition: includes() determines whether an array includes a certain element. returns TRUE or FALSE.
backcard.example: let a = [1,2,3] a.includes(2) // true a.includes(4) // false

backcard.definition: indexOf() returns the first index at which a given element can be found in the array. Returns -1 if it is not found.
slice() returns a shallow COPY of a portion of an array into a new array object selected from BEGIN (Inclusive) to END (Non-Inclusive). ORIGINAL ARRAY NOT MUTATED.
backcard.example: let a = ['zero', 'one', 'two','three'] let sliced = a.slice(1,3) a = ['zero', 'one', 'two','three'] sliced = ['one', 'two']

backcard.definition: splice() changes the contents of an array by removing existing elements and/or adding new elements.
backcard.example: let numbers = ['zero', 'one', 'two', 'three'] numbers.splice(2, 0, 'BANANA') // inserts banana at index-2 // numbers = ['zero', 'one', 'BANANA', 'two', 'three'] numbers.splice(2,1) // removes 1 item starting at index-2 // numbers = numbers = ['zero', 'one', 'three']
backcard.syntax: arr.splice(start, deleteCount, item to add to array)

backcard.definition: every() tests whether ALL ELEMENTS in the array pass the test implemented by the provided function.
backcard.example: function isBigEnough(element, index, array) { return element >= 10 } [2, 4 , 6, 8].every(isBigEnough) // false [12, 14, 16, 18].every(isBigEnough) // true

backcard.definition: charAt() returns the specified character from a string. If no index is provided, charAt() will use index-0. Will return and empty string if index is out of range.
concat() combines the text of one or more strings and returns a NEW String. ORIGINAL STRING NOT MUTATED.
includes() determines whether one string may be found within another string, returning TRUE or FALSE. CASE SENSITIVE
backcard.example: let str = 'abcdefg' str.includes('def') // True str.includes('fghi') // False

backcard.definition: slice() extracts a section of a string, from BEGIN (Inclusive) to END (Non-Inclusive), and returns it as a NEW String. ORIGINAL STRING NOT MUTATED.
substr() returns the characters in a string beginning at the specified location (index) through the specified number (length) of characters (inclusive).
substring() returns a subset of a string between one index START (inclusive) and another END (Non-Inclusive), or through the end of the string (if indexEnd is omitted).
